benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/invoicePayments/{paymentId}/tags - Retrieve payment tags

covered: Valid Request: Multiple scenarios cover successful retrieval for basic and combined query-parameter cases (TC01, TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05).
Empty Response / State Variation: TC06, TC19 and TC20 cover payments with no tags, partially populated DB and empty DB behavior.
Query Parameters: includedDeleted, pluginProperty and audit parameters exercised, including valid and invalid audit (TC02, TC03, TC04, TC05, TC10, TC11, TC17).
Error Handling: Key error cases are present — invalid ID -> 400 (TC08), not found -> 404 (TC07, TC20), missing auth -> 401 (TC09), server error -> 500 (TC24), dependency down -> 503 (TC13).
Security: Injection and XSS attempts are considered (TC15, TC16).
Performance / Large payloads: Heavy-load and large-result scenarios included (TC12, TC18).
Integration & Recovery: Dependency outage and retry-on-transient-failure covered (TC13, TC21).
Regression & Backward Compatibility: Regression test for deleted-tags bug and a backward-compatibility check are present (TC14, TC22).
Content-Type: TC01 explicitly checks response Content-Type application/json (others imply JSON responses).
gaps: Pagination: No tests exercise pagination, page size limits, ordering or cursor/offset behavior (guideline expects pagination handling).
Caching Behavior: No tests validate caching headers or conditional GET semantics (ETag, Cache-Control, If-None-Match / 304).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests simulate bursts to verify 429 responses or Retry-After headers.
Authorization (403): No explicit test for insufficient privileges (403 Forbidden) — only missing token (401) is covered.
Audit default behavior: No explicit assertion that audit defaults to NONE (i.e., absence of audit fields) when audit parameter is omitted.
Tag schema validation: Tests do not assert Tag object contract (required fields, types, enums) against /definitions/Tag.
Content-Type & header consistency: Only one scenario asserts Content-Type; headers like charset and caching are not verified across scenarios.
PluginProperty negative/unsupported cases: Missing tests for unsupported plugin properties or behavior when plugin is absent.
Concurrency / Consistency: No tests for race conditions (tags added/removed during retrieval) or concurrent access impacts.
Clarify pagination vs large payload behavior: Large-result tests check performance but do not verify slicing/streaming/transfer strategies.
recommendations: Confirm whether the endpoint supports pagination. If it does, add tests for limit/offset or cursor-based paging, stable ordering, boundary conditions (first/last page) and page-size limits. If it does not, document this explicitly and add tests ensuring very large responses are safely handled by clients/servers.
Add caching tests: assert Cache-Control, ETag and Last-Modified headers; add conditional GET tests (If-None-Match -> 304) and verify behavior on resource change.
Add rate-limiting tests: simulate request bursts to assert 429 responses, Retry-After header presence and backoff guidance.
Add authorization tests for permission-denied (403) scenarios in addition to authentication (401).
Add an explicit test asserting audit default = NONE when audit is omitted (i.e., no audit fields returned) and verify each audit level maps to the expected payload shape.
Introduce strict schema validation tests for Tag objects against /definitions/Tag (presence and types of id, name, objectType, createdDate, etc.).
Extend pluginProperty coverage: test malformed values, unsupported property keys, and behavior when the referenced plugin is not installed/available.
Add concurrency/race-condition tests: perform concurrent tag add/remove while retrieving tags to validate consistency guarantees.
Assert response headers consistently across scenarios (Content-Type with charset, caching headers, and any custom headers) rather than only in a single happy-path test.
Expand security tests to include additional input validation fuzzing and ensure error responses do not leak internal details; keep SQL injection/XSS tests automated and repeatable.
